Posts.Content: Hello Joe, I also read this book "You Can Beat Prostate Cancer And you can do it without surgery" and found it very positive. However, this book was published in 2002 and has data up to 2000. Lot of things changed or significantly improved since that time. I recommend to read recently published books like "Prostate Cancer: A New Approach to Treatment and Healing" (2016) and "Guide to Surviving Prostate Cancer" 4th addition, when it become available in bookstores some time in May.

Posts.Title: Playing the waiting game

Posts.Content: Thank you for topic. As I am still in the learning curve SBRT (CyberKnife) is one of the treatments that are on my radar, along with HR BT. The thing that looks interesting about this treatment, that it requires only 5 visits for radiation treatment vs 40-50 treatments for IMRT or PT. My only concern is that I am still unclear if it can treat the entire gland or is it more focal therapy targeting know tumors?

Posts.Title: Encouraging Radiation Study

Posts.Content: Thank you for bringing this topic. Decision making is very hard due to so much information available. "Fortunately" for me my dad went through treatment (BT/ER/HT) 8 years ago and shared his personal experience, including emotional part of PC diagnose. I believe it is very important to find someone you really trust and not just pushing its own agenda, business or bias point of view. Then study and get as much info from books, forums and support groups because every bit of information you get during learning curve will help you in the end to make best educated choice for treatment, recovery and future life.

Posts.Title: Letter to the Editor: PCa Opinions are Becoming as Intense as Politics

Posts.Content: Thank you for sharing all opinions about this subject. The book I am referring is about traditional medically proven treatments and it has only one chapter (CH10) about AS. I understand that this is controversial topic and requires lot of research and study. Right now I more inclined to think that well balanced life described in chapter 10 can slow down progression or even (possible?) halt PC for LOW Risk/Volume cases. I can also view it as preparation for treatment to boost immune system and overall health to have better recovery from potential side effects of treatment. The reason I refer this book because I studied several books on this subject as well this forum and this book has the most comprehensive overview that covers the latest updates on all available treatments in US and abroad, including many stories from doctors and patients. If someone wants to take surgery path or get in-depth knowledge on cancer causing factors, then I recommend Dr. Patrick Walsh's Guide to Surviving Prostate Cancer.

Posts.Title: Is prostate cancer irreversible?

Posts.Content: I was reading one book "Prostate Cancer: A New Approach to Treatment and Healing" where in Chapter 10 description of strategy outlined on dealing with PC if it is LOW GRADE and LOW VOLUME cancer, where it is still reversible. This strategy includes the following areas of opportunity: 1. Imflammation 2. Diet 3. Inactivity 4. Stress 5. Immune System 6. Hormones 7. Pelvic Structure 8. Toxic Substances This is only for Low risk cancer. I have a question and would like to know if anyone has any experience or knowledge on this subject. Thank you in advance.

Posts.Title: MRI-guided Nerve-sparing HDR Brachytherapy

Posts.Content: Thank you for all replies and valuable inputs. Based on biopsy results and Polaris report I am qualified for active surveillance. However, I have number of concerns before choosing AS for now: First, as you may know random TRUS biopsy is only 30% accurate and will miss 70% of cancers. To combat this uncertainty I plan on doing 3t MRI in June plus another PCA and Free PCA testing to have better understanding where I stand. Once I have this information my next step, if I have additional areas of concern, is to do MRI-Fusing biopsy for 20 cores. It is still 80% accurate, but it is better then 30% of random biopsy. As my urologist mentioned the only reason why he found cancer, because he aimed in the area of firmness discovered during DRE. Second, the location of tumor and how close it is to prostate wall. The urologist told me that he can not say where exactly the tumor is. What worries me is the procentage of core with cancer (8%). If the tumor is really small how he can fill it during DRE unless it is very close or touching the prostate wall. The other possibility if biopsy sampled the side of tumor and the actual tumor is much higher volume but deeper in prostate. If tumor is deeper in prostate then AS is very good option for now. However, if it is "touching" prostate wall then it is completely different situation and it moves me to intermediate risk group (regardless of low Gleason score) that require treatment withing one year period. This is the reason why I am trying to get information about best treatment options, as well AS. I met two radiation oncologists. Both offer IGRT. One RO uses KV CBCT (without fiducial markers). This is the same clinic that treated my father. And other RO uses IGRT but with fiducial markers. Not sure what guide system they use. Surgery is concern to me because of tumor location: Left Medial Apex. As I learned from one of the book I read, this specific area has higher possibility of leaving positive margin due to close proximity to urethra. I will consider all these treatment options once I have better understanding of current state of cancer. Right now I am looking toward AS.

Posts.Title: MRI-guided Nerve-sparing HDR Brachytherapy

Posts.Content: I am wondering if someone had any experience with this type of treatment? https://www.floridahospitalcancer.com/radiation-campaign Urologic Cancer MRI-guided Nerve-sparing HDR Brachytherapy MRI-guided nerve-sparing HDR brachytherapy is used for a wide range of prostate-cancer stages. It is a minimally invasive outpatient procedure where catheters are temporarily placed into the patients prostate. Radiation is then delivered internally through catheters. The treatment significantly limits radiation to the bladder or rectum beyond what is achievable with other external radiation treatments. After completion of treatment, the catheters are removed. Patients go home the same day. MRI-guided focal HDR Brachytherapy Prostate cancer will recur for approximately 20-30 percent of patients that have received radiation therapy. To combat this, Florida Hospital offers MRI-guided focal HDR brachytherapy. This treatment is a minimally invasive outpatient procedure that focuses treatment on the tumor while sparing the surrounding organs and reduces the risk of side effects. Florida Hospital is the only hospital in the state that offers this life-saving treatment. SpaceOAR SpaceOAR is a temporary, injectable non-toxic biodegradable gel that protects the rectum during radiation treatment for prostate cancer. The gel is placed prior to starting radiation treatment and significantly reduces the radiation dose to the rectum. The body naturally absorbs it over several weeks after completion of treatment. SpaceOAR is the first and only prostate-cancer spacing device to receive clearance from the Food and Drug Administration (FDA). No other rectum-sparing hydrogels are currently available in the United States.
